senses.de: The maximum amount that something can contain or produce
senses.ex: The stadium has a seating capacity of 50,000 people.

Tips.title: Quantitative Limits
Tips.description: Refers to specific numbers illustrating the limit of a space or object.
Tips.example: The bottle's capacity is two liters.

Tips.title: Physical Constraints
Tips.description: Indicates the physical boundaries within which something operates or fits.
Tips.example: The suitcase has a capacity of 45 kilograms.

senses.de: The ability or power to do, experience, or understand something
senses.ex: She has a great capacity for learning new languages.

Tips.title: Personal Abilities
Tips.description: Highlights a person's capability in mental or emotional terms.
Tips.example: She has the capacity to empathize with others.

Tips.title: Growth Potential
Tips.description: Refers to the potential to develop a skill or ability further.
Tips.example: He has the capacity to improve his math skills.

Tips.title: Self-development
Tips.description: Capacity can imply a person's readiness to learn or adapt to new situations.
Tips.example: Traveling alone for the first time challenged her emotional capacity.

senses.ex: He is working in the capacity of a teacher.

Tips.title: Technical Specifications
Tips.description: Used to describe technical properties, often in computers and electronics.
Tips.example: This USB drive has a capacity of 128GB.

Tips.title: Specific Terms
Tips.description: In computing, refers to data storage and memory capabilities.
Tips.example: Upgrade your RAM to increase the computer's capacity.

Tips.title: Upgrade Relevance
Tips.description: Capacity in computing often dictates device upgrade decisions.
Tips.example: A low capacity SSD may need upgrading to store more games.

senses.de: The amount that something can hold
senses.ex: The laptop has a hard drive capacity of 500 gigabytes.
He signed the contract in his capacity as the company's CEO.

Tips.title: Legal Power
Tips.description: Indicates the legal power or role given to a person or organization.
Tips.example: As a guardian, you have the capacity to make decisions for the child.

Tips.title: Authority Context
Tips.description: Used to describe the jurisdiction or range of one's authoritative role.
Tips.example: The manager has the capacity to hire new employees.

Ability.wordDefinition:
Ability refers to the capability or skill to do something. It usually refers to a specific talent, skill or competence that one possesses.

For example, someone may have the ability to cook, write, or sing.

Ability focuses on skills or talents while capacity focuses on potential or the amount something can hold. Both words are applicable in different contexts and it is important to use the correct word depending on the situation.

Aptitude.wordDefinition:
Aptitude refers to a person's natural ability or talent to do something well. It is innate and cannot be learned or acquired through training.

For example, if someone has an aptitude for music, they have a natural ability to play an instrument or sing well.

Aptitude refers to natural ability, while capacity refers to the ability to learn and acquire new skills through education and training.

Capability.wordDefinition:
Capability and capacity are two similar words with subtle differences.

Capability refers to the level of skill or ability a person or thing possesses to complete a particular task. For instance, a person may have the capability to sing well or a machine may have the capability to produce 100 units of a product in a day.

Capability is about what a person or thing can do, while capacity is about how much they can do. Capability is more about the quality of performance, whereas capacity is more focused on quantity or volume.

Capability can be used in assessing and developing individual skills, while capacity can be used in logistics and operations planning.

Competence.wordDefinition:
Competence refers to the ability to do something well or efficiently, like someone's skill set or expertise in a particular area.

So, while capacity is about how much someone or something can hold, competence is about their ability to do something well.

Capacity is applicable in fields like architecture or engineering, while competence is applicable in fields like medicine or law.

Potential.wordDefinition:
Capacity and potential are often used interchangeably, but they actually have different meanings.

Potential refers to what something or someone can become. It's the possibility of achieving something in the future. For example, a student might have the potential to become a doctor because they have the intelligence, work ethic, and desire to succeed in medical school.

Capacity is about what something or someone can do right now, while potential is about what they can become in the future.

Capacity is measurable, while potential is a possibility.

Power.wordDefinition:
Capacity and Power are both words that indicate the ability to do something, but they have different meanings and uses.

Power refers to the ability to control, influence or affect something or someone.

Power can be physical, political or economic.

For example, an athlete may have the power to lift heavy weights or a leader may have the power to make important decisions.

In physics, power is the rate at which work is done or energy is transferred.

Capacity refers to the amount of something that can be held or accommodated, while power describes the ability to control, influence or affect something or someone.

Proficiency.wordDefinition:
Proficiency refers to a person's skill or ability to do something well. For example, if someone has proficiency in playing the guitar, it means that they are skilled at playing the guitar.

Capacity is applicable when talking about how much of something can fit inside a container or space. Proficiency is applicable when discussing someone's skill or ability in a particular domain or activity.

Capacity refers to the amount that can be held, while proficiency refers to a person's skill or ability in a particular activity.

Sufficiency.wordDefinition:
Capacity refers to the maximum amount that something can hold or do, while sufficiency refers to having enough or being adequate.

In terms of usage, capacity is more commonly used in quantitative or measurable terms. In contrast, sufficiency is more often used in qualitative or subjective terms.

Talent.wordDefinition:
Talent refers to a natural ability or skill that a person possesses, such as musical talent or artistic talent.

Talent is often seen as an innate gift that can be nurtured and developed over time.

In simpler terms, capacity is about how much a person or object can handle or hold, while talent is about a person's natural abilities or strengths.

Capacity is applicable in situations where you need to determine how much of something can be accommodated or handled, while talent is used in situations where a person's abilities or strengths are relevant, such as in job interviews or career planning.

Exciting developments in the worlds of both humans and superheroes will always influence each other.

quotes.Text: I've always believed in God. I also think that's the sort of thing that either comes as part of the equipment, the capacity to believe, or at some point in your life, when you're in a position where you actually need help from a power greater than yourself, you simply make an agreement.
quotes.Title: Author
quotes.Name: Stephen King

quotes.Text: At Facebook, we build tools to help people connect with the people they want and share what they want, and by doing this we are extending people's capacity to build and maintain relationships.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Mark Zuckerberg

quotes.Text: Sometimes you see how humanity can rise above any kind of cultural ills and hate that a person's capacity to love and communicate and forgive can be bigger than anything else.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Viola Davis

quotes.Text: Meditation can help us embrace our worries, our fear, our anger; and that is very healing. We let our own natural capacity of healing do the work.
quotes.Title: Vietnamese Clergyman
quotes.Name: Thich Nhat Hanh

quotes.Text: When you stop caring what people think, you lose your capacity for connection. When you're defined by it, you lose our capacity for vulnerability.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Brene Brown

quotes.Text: The capacity for hope is the most significant fact of life. It provides human beings with a sense of destination and the energy to get started.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Norman Cousins

quotes.Text: Using the power of decision gives you the capacity to get past any excuse to change any and every part of your life in an instant.
quotes.Title: American Speaker
quotes.Name: Tony Robbins

quotes.Text: We must make the choices that enable us to fulfill the deepest capacities of our real selves.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Thomas Merton

quotes.Text: The world would be happier if men had the same capacity to be silent that they have to speak.
quotes.Title: Dutch Philosopher
quotes.Name: Baruch Spinoza

quotes.Text: People have this capacity within them to set the world straight.
quotes.Title: Canadian Psychologist
quotes.Name: Jordan Peterson
